Award.AwardTitle: Environmental Biology at Alabama A&M University (EB@aamu)
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Alabama A&M University (AAMU) to establish an Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program. The program will provide two-year research experiences in environmental biology and ecology to five cohorts of scholars, starting in the spring of 2011 and continuing through winter 2015. Each cohort consists of five students who will be trained on research involving problems related to plant biology, environmental science, and food and animal science. AAMU-URM scholars will be able to select from a wide range of research projects including microbial ecology, plant science, soil biochemistry and soil genomics, bird and bat behavior, and others. URM scholars will develop research, critical thinking, and communication skills, beyond what is typically achievable in an undergraduate classroom. By the end of their tenure in the program, scholars will be well positioned for admission into graduate programs in the environmental and ecological disciplines. The AAMU-URM students will participate in independent field or laboratory research, be mentored directly by faculty, and engage in enhancement activities to foster cohort-building, networking, and peer mentoring. The URM scholars will be selected based on their interests, career goals, academic performance, and letters of recommendation. Research performed by scholars will be presented at national or regional conferences. All AAMU-URM scholars will develop research skills that will (1) contribute directly to the greater knowledge of our ecosystems science, (2) increase visibility and awareness of biological and environmental sciences across Alabama, and (3) increase individual competitiveness for admission to graduate school. Evaluation of program success is planned through monitoring of student accomplishments and outcomes. More information is available at http://www.aamu.edu/urm/, or by contacting Elica Moss ( Elica.Moss@aamu.edu ) or Govind Sharma (govind.sharma@aamu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmental Biology@Alabama A&M University

Outcomes Report

 

The goals of the Undergraduate Research and Mentoring in the Biological Sciences (URM) program was to increase the number and diversity of individuals pursuing graduate studies in all areas of biological research and to establish innovative programs to engage undergraduates in a year-round research and mentoring activity. The Environmental Biology Program at Alabama A&M University (AAMU) {EB@aamu} prepared students with a strong interest in environmental biology to pursue an undergraduate degree while being creatively engaged in research laboratories throughout campus.  These years of the URM program have been truly exemplary for the students involved. During the course of the program, over thirty (30) students with majors in environmental science, environmental health science, plant science, soil science, food science and biology were mentored.  The program provided the opportunity for students to undertake hypothesis-driven research with research mentors in areas of soil microbiology, water quality, food science, environmental health, GIS and forestry science.  The students were able to disseminate this research through both oral and poster presentations at various conferences and meetings throughout the country.  They were more involved in their research, which afforded many of them with opportunities to present the research and thus contribute to the scientific community at National Meetings of their respective disciplines. For example, research conducted as part of the URM program has been disseminated to The American Council for Medicinally Active Plants, American Society of Agronomy, Soil Science Society of America, and Crop Science Society of America, South Eastern Society of American Foresters (SESAF), International Food Technology South-East sectional meetings for Food Science, National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChe) Conference, and the National Conference of the Wildlife Society,  the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) Conference of Research Experiences for Undergraduate Students and the HBCU Climate Change Conference.

This program encouraged students interested in a career in scientific research to think outside the box and get creative when problem solving.  The research conducted by URM students has addressed some important issues of the environmental biology and chemistry. During the years of this program, most students are able to make significant progress and findings in pursuing knowledge of their fields of interest.  Several manuscripts and scientific reports were developed and published based on the findings of the URM research.

Due to the structure and demands of the program, over fifteen (15) students have entered graduate programs in the environmental biology area.  Faculty competencies in mentoring and peer mentoring and team building have strengthened throughout the years through mentoring workshops and the continued willingness of faculty participation.

The students participating in the URM program gained so much in such a short period of time. Student scholars were engaged in numerous URM sponsored activities: guest and student seminars, journal/data club, research group meetings, and informal get-togethers with the research and academic mentors. All of these activities will unquestionably aid in their future scientific endeavors. These career building workshops also enhanced the research experience and fostered successful careers in environmental biology. 

This URM program has truly been an asset to Alabama A&M University.  It was a prestigious honor that was afforded to a select few and they thrived off the competition and rigorousness of the program with the knowledge that the preparation and skills obtained would set the course for a successful career.  One of the primary objectives was to increase the number of American students who will pursue a graduate degree in the STEM fields, especially African-Americans, and engage them in research, teaching, and management of renewable natural resources. Our success in this area has been substantial, through integrating educational/training workshops and scientific research. After graduation and receipt of their BS degree, we expected that the majority of them will pursue an advanced graduate degree.  These students have knowledge about the research field that they will pursue, but also the importance of education and research. By working in the labs, students learn to approach scientific questions from angles different from what they are accustomed to. This can contribute to their overall scientific success, through future collaborations and exchanges. We predict that many of our students will be playing leading role in research, management, and teaching fields and in state and federal agencies, private consulting, and industry in the near future.
